title: Integration Studio - ZENworks
content:
You can integrate Service Management with ZENworks. This integration enables you to import devices from ZENworks into the UCMDB and the SACM module. During the import, the system attempts to identify the device owner to assign it to the correct user in Service Management. The user in Service Management can then view all assigned devices in the Service Portal under My Services and Assets. 

Furthermore, configuration managers or administrators can run remote actions against the imported devices. For example, they can restart a device, lock it, or start a virus scan directly from the device record in Service Management.

When using remote actions to manage devices via ZENworks, it’s your responsibility to set the correct permissions in the ZENworks application to ensure the integration is not misused for harmful actions.

Supported use cases

  1. Import devices from ZENworks into Service Management, to manage them in Service Management and give endusers the abiltiy to see their devices in the self service portal
  2. Import bundles from ZENworks into Service Management, to be able to trigger a software deployment from Service Management against the device in ZENworks
  3. Execute remote actions, like Reboot, Refresh, Launch bundle, from Service Management against a device in ZENworks
The integration use cases outlined in this document are meant to inspire and guide your integration efforts. However, they should not be viewed as definitive or guaranteed solutions for your specific situation. These examples may not be applicable to your particular license edition.

Data integration flow 

Import devices

The integration can be triggered via a scheduled or manual process in Integration Studio. In this scenarios, the following events occur:
  • Pulls devices from Zenworks
  • Prepares the data for Universal CMDB
  • Creates or updates the CIs in Universal CMDB
  • Through Native SACM, the CIs are then made available in the SACM module in Service Management.

The following diagram depicts how devices are imported:

The ZENworks API currently does not support importing modified devices only. Therefore, each time the import is run, all devices will be imported.

The following details are imported with the out-of-box scenarios:

  • Device basic details like
    • Serial number
    • Processor family
    • Virtual device
    • Operating system vendor
    • Operating system family
    • Operating system description
    • Discovered model
    • Discovered vendor
    • Discovered OS build
    • Discovered OS version
    • Discovered OS name: ​
    • VMWare resource id
    • VMWare id
    • Memory size
    • Node role
    • Node family​​​
    • IMAI
    • Phone number
    • DNS  name
    • Vendor
    • ZENworks ID
  • Bios details
    • Bios uuid
    • Bios serial_number
    • Bios asset_tag
    • Bios source
    • Bios version
    • Bios date: 
  • IP address details
    • IP address
  • CPU details
    • CPU id
    • CPU vendor
    • CPU clock speed
    • Number of cores
    • CPU type
  • Owner (if identified in Service Management)
     
The following details are not imported:
  • Hard Disk details
  • Network adapter details
  • Installed software on the device
In case additional information are required to be imported, customer can adjust the integration templates.

Import bundles

The integration can be triggered via a scheduled or manual process in Integration Studio. In this scenario, the following events occur:

  • Pulls bundles from Zenworks
  • Prepares the data for the Asset Models
  • Creates or updates the Asset Models in Service Management

The following diagram depicts how bundles are imported:

The ZENworks API currently does not support importing only new or modified bundles. Therefore, each time the import is run, all bundles will be imported.

The following bundle details are imported:

  • Bundle ID
  • Bundle Name
  • Bundle Description
  • Bundle version

Set up the integration

The following Integration Studio procedure sets up the integration to prepare and use the use cases described from above. The integration process creates several scenarios based on the following templates:

  1. ZENworks – Import devices
  2. ZENworks - Import bundles
  3. ZENworks - Execute action
Those templates reflect an out-of-the-box solution for this integration.  Customers can adjust or customize the out-of-the box scenarios to enhance the integration.

Prerequisites

This solution is designed and works with Service Management in the Native SACM context, especially when importing devices. If you do not have Native SACM deployed, this solution only creates CIs in UCMDB. 

To set up the integration, make sure the following prerequisites are satisfied

Network connectivity

The Service Management system must be able to directly connect to the ZENworks system. The On-Premise-Bridge is not supported for the scenario template ZENworks – Import Devices.

ZENworks Credentials

This integration requires a ZENworks service client (OAUTH2 client id and secret) created with proper ZENworks rights to manage devices and bundles.

Configurations in UCMDB

Go to the CI type manager in UCMDB, select CI type Node, and add a new field zenworks_id of type string.

Configurations in Service Management

  •  In Service Management, go to Administration -> Studio, and select the Device entity.
  • Create a new field ZenworksID of type SMALL_TEXT. Make it a federated field and select the Zenworks ID field created in UCMDB.
  • [Optional] Create a new field ZenworksURL of type URL. If customers require a direct hyperlink from the device record in Service Management to the ZENworks UI, this field is required. This would allows users to directly open the device in the ZENworks control center.

Prepare an integration user in Service Management

Perform the following steps to prepare an integration user:

  1. Create an integration user. See How to create an integration user.

  2. Log in to the Agent Interface as the tenant admin.

  3. Navigate to Administration > Master Data > People, locate the integration user, and then assign the proper roles to access the SACM module.

    1. For Service Management, the role must have the necessary permissions to update Device records.
    2. To import bundles from ZENworks, ensure the role has permissions to create and update Asset Models. Alternatively, add the Tenant Admin role to grant general access.
    3. For UCMDB, specify a role that allows creating and updating CIs.

Create endpoints

The following section explains how to create endpoints for Zenworks and UCMDB.

Zenworks

Create an endpoint using the Rest Executor 2.0 endpoint type:

  1. Log in to the agent interface as the tenant admin.

  2. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Endpoints.

  3. Click Add.

  4. Select Rest Executor 2.0 as the endpoint type, enter a name for the endpoint (for example, ZENworks), and then click Add. The system creates the endpoint.

  5. Click Configure and follow the instructions provided in the following section.

Use agentless endpoint

To use an agentless endpoint, configure your Service Management instance to connect directly to the ZENworks API as documented here:

Field Value

Authentication type Select OAuth 2.0

Certificate format Leave it empty.

Enable email notification for expired token Optional

Get Token configuration
Grant Type

Token URL The ZENworks OAUTH2 token URL. Like https://<ZENworks FQDN>/osp/a/zenworks/auth/oauth2/token
Scope

Send client ID and secret In body
Universal CMDB
Create another endpoint for UCMDB. This second endpoint is required to create and update the CIs directly in UCMDB. 

Configure the fields as shown in the table below:

Create an integration

To create an integration based on the Microsoft Graph connector, follow these steps. 

  1. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Integration Studio. 

  2. Click New, enter the name of your integration, and then click Save. The system displays the Integration page.
  3. In the Details section, configure the integration user you created for the current Service Management system and activate the integration.
  4. In the Connector-Endpoint mappings section:
    1. Click Add to add a mapping -> Enter an alias for the mapping. Example: For ZENworks, select ZENworks as the connector, and select the ZENworks endpoint you created earlier.
    2. Click Add another mapping -> Enter an alias for the mapping. Example: For UCMDB, select Universal CMDB as the connector, and select the UCMDB endpoint you created earlier.
  5. Click Save. 

Create using ZENworks - Import devices scenario template

Configure the scenario

Perform the following steps to add and configure a scenario using the predefined template:

  1. Click Add scenario. 

  2. Enter a name for the scenario. For example, enter ZENworks – Import devices.

  3. In the Template field, select ZENworks – Import devices from the list. 

  4. Click Save to add the scenario. 

  5. Configure the parameters described below, and then click Save.

Parameters to consider before using the scenario

In the Settings rule at the beginning of the process logic section, you can use the following parameters to control the scenario's behavior.

Parameter Description
sleepTimeInMinutes
The time to wait in minutes to ensure that the CI added to UCMDB are synchronized to Service Management via the Native SACM functionality.
Once this time has passed, the Service Management data can be enriched with the owner's information and the ZENworks URL of the device.
keepNullValues If set to true, null values from ZENworks properties are retained as null and forwarded to the Universal CMDB, resulting in field values being left empty in the Universal CMDB.  If this value is set to false, the system will ignore null values and therefore will not update the field in Universal CMDB.
enrichOTSMOwner If this parameter is set to true, the scenario is trying to find the owner of the ZENworks device in the Service Management database. If identified, the Owner property is populated with the user name.
enrichOTSMDrilldownUrl
If this parameter is set to true, the scenario adds a link to the ZENWorks device to the device record in Service Management.
By setting this to true, the custom property ZENworksURL must be available in the Device entity. (see prerequisites)
ZenworksBaseURL
The OTSM base URL. 
This parameter is required when the parameter enrichOTSMDrilldownUrl is set to true.
ZenworksUrlExtension The URL to navigate directly to the record.
userIdentificationProperty
Specifies which property in the Service Management Person entity is used to identify the user of the device.
This parameter is required when the parameter enrichOTSMOwner is set to true.

In the step Query parameters, define the initial parameters to influence the ZENworks response.

Parameter Description
size
The number of records to fetch from ZENworks per call. 
initialFields The initial fields to fetch when the list of devices is queried.
page The starting page.
final The final query parameters for the execution of the request.
Run the scenario
To run the scenario, create a scheduler in Integration Studio that imports all devices from ZENworks on a regular basis.
Additional information

If the custom properties are named differently from what is documented here, adjust the scenario according to the following steps:

  1. zenworks_id (created in UCMDB)
    1. This property is used in step 3 - Runtime data.
    2. Go to the key node template, and modify the property name in the value column associated with that key.
  2. ZENWorks_URL (created in Service Management)
    1. This property is used in step 31 - Service Management Update device record.
    2. In the payload section, please ensure that you adjust the field name as needed.

Create using ZENworks - Import bundles scenario template

Configure the scenario

Perform the following steps to add and configure a scenario using the predefined template:

  1. Click Add scenario. 

  2. Enter a name for the scenario. For example, enter ZENworks – Import bundles.

  3. In the Template field, select ZENworks – Import bundles from the list. 

  4. Click Save to add the scenario. 

  5. Configure the parameters described below, and then click Save.

Parameters to consider before using the scenario

In the Settings rule at the beginning of the process logic section, you can use the following parameters to control the scenario's behavior.

Parameter Description
ParentAssetModel
The parent Asset Model as category where all the imported bundles are added as child models.
ModelType The type of the Asset Model to use.

In the step Query parameters, define the initial parameters to influence the ZENworks response.

Parameter Description
size
The number of records to fetch from ZENworks per call. 
page The starting page.
final The final query parameters for the execution of the request.
Run the scenario
To run the scenario, create a scheduler in Integration Studio that imports all bundles from ZENworks on a regular basis.
Additional information

The ID of the bundle is stored in the ExternalReference property of the Asset Model entity.

Create using ZENworks – Execute action scenario template

The Execute action scenario allows customers to run various actions against the devices in ZENworks. An action can restart a device, but also deploy new software packages or launch specific scripts.

Perform the following steps to add and configure a scenario using the predefined template:

  1. Click Add scenario. 

  2. Enter a name for the scenario. For example, enter ZENworks – Execute action.

  3. In the Template field, select ZENworks – Execute action from the list. 

  4. Click Save to add the scenario. 

  5. Configure the parameters described below, and then click Save.

This template is pre-configured to run simple actions, such as reboot or refresh. Other remote actions from ZENworks may require changes in the payload sent to ZENworks to trigger the action correctly.

Parameters to consider before using the scenario

In the Settings rule at the beginning of the process logic section, you can use the following parameters to control the scenario's behavior.

These parameters are typically sent from the calling application, such as an automated task or a business rule. See example below.

Parameter Description
Action
The action to execute against the ZENworks device.
Note: Some actions require different payloads. Please check ZENworks API description.
User The Service Management username that triggered the integration.
DeviceId The ZENworks device ID to run the remote action against.
BundleId The ZENworks bundle ID to install a software bundle. Only required when the action "launchBundle" is triggered.
FriendlyActionName (Optional) Provides the possiblity to convert the ZENworks remote action names into user friendly value.
Run the scenario
To run the scenario, different possibilities exist. The following 2 options are examples on how such an action can be triggered.
Run scenario by using a custom action
Add a Custom Action
  1. Go to Service Management Studio and select the Device entity.
  2. Go to the Custom Actions tab.
  3. Create an Action group with the name ZENworks.
  4. Create a custom action.
    1. Name: Zenworksreboot. (ensure the action name is correctly spelled in lower case).
    2. Display name: Reboot.
    3. Enable workflow: true.
    4. Select an icon.
    5. Position in record page: Show as primary.
    6. Group in record page: Select your Action Group.
    7. Position in grid page: Do not show.
  5. Save the action
Add a business rule to trigger the execution of the remote action when the custom action is clicked.
  1. Go to Service Management Studio and select the Device entity.
  2. Go to Processes and Rules tab.
  3. Go to After applying changes  section and add a new rule.
    1. Rule type: Call integration studio.
    2. Condition: indexof(entity.CustomActionName_c, 'Zenworks')==0 && current_update.CustomActionCount_c.IsChanged Note: The rule is only triggered when the custom action name contains Zenworks.
    3. Integration: Select the integration.
    4. Scenario: Select the scenario e.g. ZENworks - Execute action.
    5. Payload: Add the following key / value pairs.
      Left column content 
      (key)
      		 Right column content (value) Description
      ZenworksId  fx: ${entity.ZenworksID_c}    The reference to the Zenworks ID field, created in the prerequisites section
      Action fx: ${substring(entity.CustomActionName_c,8,length(entity.CustomActionName_c))} The expression will extract the ZENworks action name from the custom action name, e.g. "reboot" in the custom action created above
      User fx: ${current_user.Name} The name of the user who triggered the action
Those keys and their values are passed to the integation studio scenario for usage in the scenario.
Once the custom action and business rule are added, go to the Device records imported by the ZENworks - Import Devices scenario and click the custom action to trigger the remote action in ZENworks.
Deploy a software bundle from a service catalog offering via task plan

It is possible to run the remote actions from the task plan of an offering. For example, to trigger the installation of a software bundle. To implement this example, complete the following steps.

Create a service offering

  • General tab - example data
    • Title & Description: "Install Adobe Acrobat Reader" with the following:
    • Status: Active
    • Required Asset Information: Device
    • Offered Asset Model: Select a record from the imported ZENworks bundles. For example: Adobe Acrobat Reader
  • Default values tab
    • Select a service, an impact, an urgency, a service desk group, a owner and a category
    • By selecting those values, the request enters the fulfillment phase automatically
  • Task plan tab
    • Select the Fulfill tab
    • Create a new automated task
      • Give the task a title, description and set an assignment group.
      • Add a business rule of type Call Integration Studio.
      • Select the ZENworks integration and the ZENworks - Execute action scenario.
      • In the Payload (optional) parameter enter the following values. These details are passed to the scenario.
        Left column content 
        (key)
        		 Right column content (value) Description
        Action launchBundle The ZENworks action to run. 
        ZenworksId fx: ${entity.RegisteredForDevice.ZenworksID_c} The reference to the Zenworks ID field, created in the prerequisites section
        BundleId fx: ${entity.RequestsOffering.ComposedByAssetModel.ExternalReference} The reference to the Bundle ID field in the Asset Model. The Bundle ID is stored in the ExternalRefernce  field.
        User fx: ${current_user.Name} The name of the user who triggered the action

With such an offering, an end user can request Adobe Acrobat Reader from the Self Service Portal. The system will automatically start the fulfillment of the request. If the deployment was successful, the request is automatically moved to the Accept phase.
